ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
(Statistics)


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Labour (a) what was the number of applications in 1961 from employees for withdrawals of monies to their credit in the Central Provident Fund; (b) the number of such applications from persons who were unemployed for more than 6 months and were over the age of 40; and (c) the number of such applications from unemployed persons aged over 40 which have been acceded to by the Central Provident Fund Board.

    Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to (a) is: there were 6,557 formal applications made in 1961 by employees to withdraw their monies standing to their credit in the Central Provident Fund.

    As regards (b), persons who are unemployed are normally not eligible to withdraw their contributions to the Central Provident Fund unless exceptionally they satisfy the conditions set out in paragraph (f) of the definition "date of withdrawal" in section 2 of the Central Provident Fund Ordinance which reads as follows:

    '"date of withdrawal" means the day... on which any member of the Fund:-

    (f) is in the opinion of the Board not likely to

    be employed in a contributor's employment

    again after having ceased to he an employee

    for a period of not less than two years;'.

The number of applications from persons who are unemployed for more than six months and over the age of 40 is not ascertainable from the Board's records.

    As regards (c), here again, Mr Speaker, no figures are available of persons who are unemployed and over the age of 40 and who have had their applications acceded to by the Central Provident Fund Board. However, some 837

Column: 114

persons have been allowed to withdraw their contributions under paragraph (f) of the definition of "date of withdrawal" found in section 2 of the Central Provident Fund Ordinance. Of these persons, 229 are married women engaged in household duties, 411 had left to reside and work in the Federation of Malaya, and the remaining 197 were mostly members who have become substantially self-employed or who are out of work and seem unlikely for reasons of health or otherwise to enter further employment.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): I am obliged to the Minister for the information he has given, Mr Speaker. But recognising the principle that the Provident Fund is to assist persons on a rainy day, does he not recognise that many of these 6,000 applications which have been rejected are from persons in dire need -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member is embarking on an expression of opinion and inviting a debate. Is there a supplementary question?

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, would the Minister consider introducing an amendment to the Central Provident Fund Ordinance in order to the Provident Fund Board to allow applications for withdrawals in circumstances which are meritorious?

    Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I remember correctly, the Member for Anson in this House raised this question once before, and I made it quite clear that the objects of this Fund are such that I am afraid my answer at the moment to his supplementary question asking me to consider an amendment is "no".

BANK SERVICE IN SINGAPORE
(Request for legislation)


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether the Government would consider introducing legislation to enforce a minimum standard of service from banks in Singapore,

STATE BANK


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether the Government would consider establishing a State Bank.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Would the hon. Member please inform the House what sort of State bank he wishes the Government to consider establishing?

    Mr David Marshall: Any bank, Sir, such as every other State in the world has. I am rather surprised that he should need a clarification.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, different States have different types of State banks. Some State banks are for special purposes, such as to provide credit to farmers and they are called Farmers' Banks. Again some other types of State banks provide easy credit facilities for industrial banks, and they are called State industrial banks. There are Co-operative State banks and a whole range of types of State banks. I am not trying to be facetious, Mr Speaker, Sir, when I ask the hon. Member for a clarification on this point because there are different types of State banks.

    However, the Member says that every State has got a State bank. I presume he means a Central Bank. Am I right in this understanding?

    Mr David Marshall: The question is a simple one, Sir. Is the Government considering the creation of any State bank?

Column: 116



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The Government already has a State bank and that is the Post Office Savings Bank.

    Mr David Marshall: Taking it seriously, Sir, is the Minister then indicating to the House that the Government has no intention to establish any Central or other State bank?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Now we come to it, Mr Speaker, Sir. As I said, he was really referring to a Central Bank. The answer is "no". The reason is quite simple. I do not know whether I should go into any details on the functions and purposes of a Central Bank and their role in the financial system of a country. Perhaps I should not. I can give the reasons quite simply. The Federation of Malaya has a Central Bank and, after merger, I have no doubt this Central Bank will establish branches in Singapore and the Borneo territories. It is, therefore, quite unnecessary for the Singapore Government to consider setting up a Central Bank of its own.

    A Central Bank such as most independent nations have is only worthy of its name and status if it is, in addition to performing the necessary functions of government bankers and the lender of last resort to commercial banks, also the authority to control the monetary issue of the country, that is, the note issue of the country, and as a corollary it acts as a custodian of the nation's foreign exchange reserve. We do not have a currency of our own, and therefore to have a Central Bank of our own, while we are part of the common currency area together with the Borneo territories and the Federation of Malaya, is quite a meaningless affair.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would ask the Minister, accepting his thesis that a Central Bank is not necessary in the light of the merger proposals, would he not consider that in the context of the stature of Singapore in the commercial and financial field, a State Commercial Bank is imperative for our own commercial needs?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, my own appraisal is that our banking requirements are adequately met by the private commercial banks. But if the Member

Column: 117

for Anson thinks otherwise and if he could convince me that there is a gap in the range of services which the private banks are performing and which a further State Commercial Bank would perform, then I shall be very happy to consider his proposal.

STATUTORY LAW REVISION ADVISORY COMMITTEE


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether Government would consider introducing legislation for the establishment of a Statutory Law Revision Advisory Committee to include members from the Bench, the Bar, the Chambers of Commerce, Trade Unions and women's organisations.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, while the Government accepts the need for the establishment of a Law Revision Committee from time to time, it is felt that it would be wrong to establish a permanent Statutory Committee with its powers set out and circumscribed by legislation. It is, however, proposed to seek the views of the Judges and the Bar Committee to explore the possibility of setting up from time to time Law Revision Committees to deal with particular aspects of the law which need revision.

    Mr David Marshall: I appreciate the indications given by the Minister. But would he not consider that a permanent committee which has to meet and has this responsibility of regularly meeting and considering the need for revision would far better meet the requirements of fast-changing circumstances than ad hoc committees from time to time?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have traced the history of Law Revision Committees elsewhere and we have found in all the Commonwealth countries that they are never appointed on a permanent statutory basis and given well defined powers. As the need arises, these Statutory Revision Committees are appointed. If the Member for Anson has any ideas on the subject, and if he

Column: 118

were to write in to us making suggestions, we would consider the setting up of a Law Revision Committee to look into those aspects of the law which require amendment or revision. These are essentially technical committees, Mr Speaker, Sir, If the Member for Anson feels very strongly that there should be amendments to particular laws, there is nothing to prevent him from introducing a Private Member's Bill.

LEGISLATION ON USE OF "SINGAPORE" BY FIRMS AND
ASSOCIATIONS


    6. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether Government would consider introducing legislation to license the use of the word "Singapore" by firms and associations.

Column: 119



    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, this question concerns the Societies Ordinance, the Companies Ordinance and the Business Names Ordinance.

    Under the Societies Ordinance, we have not refused approval of the name or any Association because the use of the word "Singapore".

    The State Advocate-General, to whom this question was referred, because his Ministry is also concerned, is unable to advise me because the question is too vague to admit of a reply. He would like to know whether the questioner intended that the use of the word "Singapore" by firms and associations be allowed or restricted.

    Mr David Marshall: I am indebted to the Minister, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am all too conscious that expatriates have impertinently arrogated to themselves the use of the word "Singapore".

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member for Anson must get use to the idea of asking just supplementary questions and not inviting a debate.

    Mr David Marshall: They are arrogating to themselves the exclusive right to the use of the word "Singapore". I have in mind the Singapore Chamber of Commerce, the Singapore Club. Now we restrict the use of our flag as an emblem to be -

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Anson is now entering into a debate. What is the supplementary question?

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, should we not introduce legislation to license the use of the word "Singapore" so that we could control its proper use?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Anson could put up his view on this matter, with specific examples, I shall submit it to the State Advocate-General for his views to see whether we could insist on these societies, if they are registered societies, to change their names.

PASSPORTS TO SINGAPORE CITIZENS


    7. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether any citizen of Singapore has been refused a passport since 1st June, 1959, and the number of such applications refused.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as can be ascertained from the records, there have been since 1st June, 1959, 15 cases of Singapore citizens who were refused passports.

    Mr David Marshall: Could the Minister indicate the reasons for such refusal and whether it is normal constitutionally to refuse exit permits to citizens?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, these persons were refused passports because (1) there were security objections against them which made it undesirable for them to be given facilities to go abroad, or (2) they were persons of doubtful standing and reliability who may cause the Government embarrassment abroad. To quote an example. There were in the past hitch-hikers of doubtful means who were stranded abroad and had subsequently to be repatriated to Singapore at public expense after causing considerable embarrassment in the country to which they had gone. Mr Speaker, Sir, the issue of passports is a privilege and not a right.

BANKING BILL
First Reading


2.52 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to provide for the licensing and regulation of the business of banking, and to amend certain provisions of the Companies Ordinance (Chapter 174 of the Revised Edition)."

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Now, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Please proceed.

Column: 121



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, I lay upon the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in respect of the Banking Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are copies of the Bill available for the use of Members?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, Sir.

    Copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation that the Bill be proceeded with. I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Hon. Members may recall that this Bill was first introduced to the Assembly at the June 1961 sitting, and since then the Bill has lapsed. The contents of the Bill before the House now are the same as those introduced in June last year, and except for minor changes in dates and in the bringing of the Schedule up to date, there has not been any material change. The main purpose of the Bill is to secure proper control over the activities of the banks in Singapore and to provide proper supervision to ensure a sound basis for banking business which is so important to the State.

    The provisions of this Bill are modelled on the lines of the Banking Ordinance and the Central Bank Ordinance now in force in the Federation of Malaya. It is desirable that Singapore and the Federation should have parallel banking legislation as the banking system is common to both territories. The Banking Bill now before the House has been held in abeyance since June 1961, because of more urgent business that has occupied the House since the present Session began. It is now being re-introduced on a Certificate of Urgency. I am proceeding with this Bill throughout its three stages because of the recurrence of industrial disputes between certain local banks and their employees. These disputes have resulted

Column: 122

in considerable inconvenience to the public and to the trading and business community in the inter-bank clearance of cheques, and ths has interfered with the efficiency of the banking business in the State. At the moment, the Malayan Banking Association operates a mutual inter-bank clearing house with three of the bigger banks serving as clearing hunks. There is provision in the Bill for the setting up of a Clearing House by the Government and, if this Clearing House is set up, on the coming into force of the Ordinance, the inconvenience that arises out of any industrial dispute will be restricted in its effect.

    The Bill before the House is a fairly straightforward one and only a few words of explanation are necessary.

    Part I makes the necessary definitions. Banking business is defined very broadly and is not intended to limit any legitimate banking business.

    Part II is devoted to the licensing of banks. This Part provides that only banks holding licences from the Minister can carry on business in Singapore. Provision is made for conditions to be attached to licences and these conditions can be modified as and when necessary. The object of this section, is to ensure that banks which operate in the State have a sound financial structure and that their business integrity is not open to question. All new banks - whether local or foreign - have to obtain a licence. Existing banks which were incorporated before 1st January, 1962, will be given a licence. They will, however, have to satisfy certain capital requirements. In the case of new banks incorporated after 1st January, 1962, if its Head Office is in Singapore, its paid-up capital must be at least $2 million. If the Head Office is situated outside Singapore, its paid-up capital must be at least $5 million and it must hold at least $2 million in Singapore in respect of business in Singapore either in the form of immovable property or other approved assets. Existing banks incorporated before 1st January, 1962, will be given a period of grace of up to 10 years under Part VI to comply with the capital requirements.

Column: 123



    Part III sets out the main duties of licensed banks. Most of the duties set out in this Part will not in any way cause well established banks to depart from their existing practices and policies. There is provision for a licensed bank to inform the Minister of any alteration in the Bank's constitution or of any proposed change in ownership. Every licensed bank is also required to maintain a reserve fund to be built up out of its profits in the manner prescribed n the Bill. The reserve fund will of course greatly increase the soundness of the bank. Licensed banks are also not allowed to pay dividends until its capitalised expenditure has been written off; nor can it grant unsecured loans exceeding $5,000 to any of its directors or any firm in which the directors are interested. Certain other requirements are also set out to ensure the financial soundness of the bank. Certain statistics are also required to be furnished to the Inspector of Banks for the protection of depositors and to assist in the control of banks. A bank that considers that it is unable to meet financial obligations is required to inform the Minister. Licensed banks are also required to appoint auditors to be approved by the Minister.

    Part IV of the Bill deals with the powers of the Minister. In this Part the Bill differs from that of the Federation of Malaya Ordinance, where the Central Bank exercises the principal functions laid down in their Ordinance. Since we do not have a Central Bank, it is necessary to set up some other authority which can perform these functions. Provision is made for the Minister to establish a clearing house.

    An Inspector of Banks is to be appointed to be the authority to undertake investigations of banks both on a routine basis and when the Minister has reason to believe that a licensed bank is carrying on its business in an unsatisfactory way. The Inspector may also, on the advice of the Minister, assume control or exercise supervision over the business of a licensed bank in certain circumstances to protect the interests of depositors and creditors. But these are reserve powers which will be used only when the need arises. The powers of the Minister, which can be delegated to the

Column: 124

Inspector of Banks, does not extend, however, to authorising enquiries specifically into the affairs of any individual customer of a licensed bank.

    Part V of the Bill makes general provisions such as barring certain individuals from taking part in the management of a licensed bank, for instance a bankrupt or persons convicted of an offence involving fraud. Other clauses state the penalty for offences and amendments to the Companies Ordinance.

    Part VI makes provisions for the transitional period. I have already referred to the provision that existing banks incorporated before 1st January, 1962, will he granted a licence.

    Clause 34 (2) allows a period of grace of up to 10 years for banks with less than $2 million paid-up capital or $2 million worth of assets in the State to adjust their assets to the amount required under this Bill. Banks with their Head Offices in Singapore will not he affected by this provision as none of them have a paid-up capital of less than $2 million. The position of branch banks with Head Offices abroad will have to he ascertained in due course.

    I should mention here, Mr Speaker, Sir, that clause 34 of the Bill, which is modelled on section 32 of the Federation Banking Ordinance, differs from the Federation Ordinance in an important respect. Under section 32 (2) (c) of the Federation Banking Ordinance, banks which are principally owned by foreign governments will not be granted a licence in the Federation of Malaya. This part of the Federation of Banking Ordinance is omitted from the Bill now before the House.

    These are the main provisions of the Bill. Hon. Members can see that there is nothing in the Bill that is meant to curtail legitimate banking business. To banks which have operated on sound banking principles, this Bill should not cause anxiety or trouble.

    As regards staffing arrangements to administer the provisions of this Bill, I intend to appoint the Deputy Controller of Foreign Exchange to be the Inspector of Banks under clause 17. He will he assisted by an adequate number of

Column: 125

subordinate staff. Two officers of the Exchange Control have been sent in the second half of last year to undergo a special training course kindly arranged by the Central Bank of the Federation of Malaya. Arrangements to set up the Government Clearing House are well under way and the Clearing House should he in operation in a few days' time.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

3.09 p.m.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I always view with repugnance any effort to rush through this House measures of an important character and it cannot be doubted that this measure is of an important character. However, I accept the Minister's reason for the Certificate of Urgency as valid. It is a significant commentary on the irresponsibility of the Malayan Banks Association in seeking to inconvenience members of the public by curtailing inter-bank clearances cheques when one of their members has an industrial dispute that today we should have to deal on the basis of urgency with this Bill instead of the normal procedure whereby I, for one, would have wished to see that an adequate opportunity be given both to the banks and to the commercial community to make representations.

    There is one aspect of the Bill. Sir, which I do not quite follow. A radical distinction is made between those banks which are in existence now and those who seek fresh licences. Under the provisions of clause 3 (4), the Minister may grant licences with or without conditions, or refuse a licence. But under clause 34 (1), which over-rules the provisions of sub-clause 4, it says that the banks specified in the Third Schedule, which are the banks in existence now, shall be granted a licence subject to such conditions as are contained in any licence which is in existence. So that, Sir, we cannot impose more conditions than are in existence, nor can we impose any

Column: 126

conditions in the licence if, in fact, there are no conditions in any existing licence or no conditions at all. I am sure there must he some valid reason for this distinction and particularly for the limitation of the Minister's powers to place conditions in respect of the issue of licenses to banks which are in existence and which are listed in the Schedule. I would appreciate an indication of the reasons which underlie the distinction between licences granted to new banks and licences granted to existing banks. I do not know, Sir, but I should imagine there are banks in existence today which have no conditions attached to any licence, and in so far as I read clause 34 (1), it precludes the Minister from imposing any conditions on the licence that he issues to those banks, tying his hands completely. I would ask whether, in fact, that is intentional or inadvertent, and if intentional the reason therefor. I would also appreciate an assurance that this Clearing House which the Government is setting up with such commendable speed will, in fact, be adequately organised for the purpose of meeting inter-bank cheque clearances to avoid the type of inconvenience which has been imposed upon the public by members of the Malayan Banks Association recently.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, a Bill of such a nature would, in my opinion, be a step in the right direction to protect the interests of depositors although I feel that it is not adequate enough. Sir, we have seen in this country too many mushroom bogus employment agencies, bogus insurance companies, and I feel that unless such a Bill is passed, we may also see in the near future, bogus banking companies.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in my opinion the Bill is not adequate because, although the Minister is given sufficient powers to investigate into the affairs of the banks, yet the depositors and the public at large do not know the results of such investigations until the situation has worsened so badly that the Minister or the Inspector has to take action.

Column: 127



    I feel that the details given by the banks to the Minister as set out in the First Schedule should also be disclosed in the banking premises so that the depositors will know what happens to the banks.

    Sir, although the bank in theory belongs to the directors, and also, to a lesser extent, to the shareholders who do not play a large part in its direction, the depositors have as much a stake in the bank as, and sometimes even more than, the directors.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, another point to which I wish to draw the attention of the Minister is that he should be given powers so that he can direct the Inspector to go and test check the cash position and other details of the banks as set out in the First Schedule and not just rely on the balance sheets.

    Mr Speaker. Sir, the ideal situation, of course, is to set up a Central Bank, but it is a practical impossibility because we are still in the stage of a semi-colony, but we hope with this Banking Bill we will have more sound banking practices and systems than has been the case in the past.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to oppose this Bill not because of the content of the Bill. The content of the Bill is praiseworthy. In fact, it was praiseworthy in June 1961 when the Government introduced it, and if there had been no intervening motives which have now induced the Government to introduce this Bill at this stage, the content would still be very praiseworthy. But what makes this Bill objectionable at the moment is the manner in which it is being presented to the House and the time at which it has been presented to this House - I repeat the phrase "the time" and I think the Minister for Finance understands very well what I mean by the phrase "the time at which he has presented this Bill". It is objectionable and unworthy of this Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore is a trading island which has commercial facilities and the banks play a very important part in the commercial prosperity of this

Column: 128

island. Now, as banks are employers, therefore there must be employees. The business of the Government, as I see it, is to foster the economic conditions of this country, and in the fostering of these economic conditions, it becomes necessary to foster the banking facilities available to this commercial community. In the absence of State banks and State commercial banks, the Minister has himself said, in answer to a question by the Member for Anson, that the private banks are in fact adequately meeting the needs of the commercial community. As the Minister concerned in these bathing facilities, he is satisfied that these banks are, in fact, providing an adequate service and he knows of no instance where they have fallen down on their obligations or failed the commercial community. Why then, I ask, are we being presented with the Banking Bill today, and why does the Minister ask that it be taken through all the stages at one sitting? The Minister introduced the Bill in 1961. He said that because he had other urgent business he had allowed the Bill to lapse. I do not accept the explanation for one moment. Mr Speaker.

    He has other motives for introducing this Bill of which he has not told this House. On the aspects of the Government's motives in introducing this Bill, they should be ashamed. My colleague, the Member for Cairnhill, will be dealing more adequately with that aspect of the situation later on in this debate. Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not wish to touch upon those motives which have led the Minister to introduce this Bill at this particular juncture. The motives indicate that the Minister for Finance is taking sides in disputes which do not concern him as the Minister for Finance.

    The Member for Anson has said that in theory he disapproves of Bills being brought into this House and passed on Certificates of Urgency when the issues involved are vital to this country, and yet he has said that in this case he is going to excuse the Government. I wonder what has happened to the sense of justice of the Member for Anson in this particular instance? Has he got a phobia against the banks?

Column: 129



    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister in his Second Reading said that the reasons for the Bill are the proper control and the proper supervision of banks. Now is he suggesting that any of the certified banks listed in the Third Schedule has contravened any of these reasons? Are the banks or any of the banks misbehaving so badly in their banking business - I mean. Mr Minister, not in their relationships over which the Minister has no Concern? Or should not -

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Farrer Park should address the Chair and not the Minister.
